DataElement.preferredName: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Finding Metaphase Process Laboratory Procedure Outcome Percentage 0 Decimal Place Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The 0 decimal place numeric laboratory value measured, assigned or computed related to the assessment of philadelphia chromosome positive metaphases found via fluorescence in situ hybridization.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Finding Metaphase Process
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping._A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML)._A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism._The second phase of mitosis, in which the chromosomes line up across the equatorial plane of the spindle prior to separation.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization Philadelphia Chromosome

This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.:A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.
A translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. It is the hallmark for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

Property.preferredDefinition: An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.:Arrangement of chromosomes in the equatorial plane of the central spindle to form the monaster.  Chromosomes separate into exactly similar halves. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
The second phase of mitosis, in which the chromosomes line up across the equatorial plane of the spindle prior to separation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
